Eucharistic Miracles:
God Under the Microscope

“The God of the Bible is also the God of the genome. God can be found in the cathedral or in the laboratory.”

— Francis Collins (1950-)
Head of the Human Genome Project, Director of NIH

By the Editorial Staff
Updated 11/1/2023

This article is a lengthy meta-analysis of a series of miracles that have occurred (and continue to occur) in Catholic parishes around the world. These events have been studied by reputable scientists and laboratories over the last ~50 years, and this article contains lab reports, interviews with the scientists involved, microscope images, and other evidence for your perusal. If you want to just read the summary, check out the “Eucharistic Miracles at a Glance” section below. Enjoy!

Eucharistic Miracles at a Glance

5 Investigations, 3 Continents, 40+ Years

Hundreds of “Eucharistic miracles,” where consecrated bread turned into human flesh and/or blood, have been reported over the last 2,000 years.

Since the 1970s, the Catholic Church has enlisted secular institutions to investigate samples from 5 of these events. Techniques included histological studies, electron microscopy, immunohistochemical tests, and thin-layer chromatography.

The map below shows the location and year of each sample that was investigated (yes, the Lanciano sample is ancient).

Credentials of the Investigators

Investigators included eminent professors of pathology and scientists in accredited laboratories across the world. Most did not know where the samples had come from before reporting their results. Examples:

Profs. Maria Sobaniec-Łotowska and Stanisław Sulkowski, anatomical pathologists with hundreds of peer-reviewed publications, at Medical University of Bialystok, which is ranked #37 university in Poland (US News).

Pomeranian Medical University, ranked #25 university in Poland.

Dr. Eduardo Sánchez Lazo, a professor of Legal and Forensic Medicine at National Autonomous University of Mexico, ranked #1 university in Mexico.

Dr. Frederick Zugibe, chief medical examiner of Rockland County, New York for 33 years and Adjunct Associate Professor of Pathology at Columbia University, ranked top 10 university in the world.

Summary of the Findings

All 5 investigations identified heart tissue under the microscope with visible muscle fibers. 

2 investigations characterized the samples as type AB, a rare blood type present in 7% of humans.

Signs ruling out human interference:

In Sokolka, the host was inextricably linked with the flesh. Professor Maria Sobaniec-Łotowska: “This remarkable phenomenon of the intermingling of the Communion and the fibers of the heart muscle observed in both light microscopes and transmission electron microscopy also demonstrates to me that there could be no human interference here.”

In Tixtla, blood was found to have flowed out from inside the host, ruling out the possibility that someone planted the blood on the host. Professor Eduardo Sánchez Lazo: “The possibility that the bleeding comes from the outside inwards is ruled out.”

In Lanciano, no preservatives were found, although the tissues were kept intact for centuries. Dr. Odoardo Linoli: “It should also be noted that no histological section showed elements indicative of an impregnation of the tissue by mummifying substances, such as those used in ancient times for the preservation of tissues.”

Scientific Integrity and Hygiene

The Catholic Church has conducted thorough scientific investigations to rule out fraud or natural explanations for various reported Eucharistic miracles, even beyond the 5 events mentioned here. For example, the Church debunked a reported Eucharistic miracle in 2015 in Salt Lake City in USA as a natural phenomenon caused by bread mold (see Salt Lake Tribune article). In contrast, the 5 miracles listed on this page stood up to scientific scrutiny, confirming the discovery of human cardiac muscle in all instances.

However, a major limitation of the 1970 investigation in Lanciano, Italy is that it was conducted entirely by one person: Dr. Odoardo Linoli, head of the laboratory of clinical analysis and pathological anatomy of the hospital of Arezzo.

The other investigations had tighter standards for chain of custody and blinding methodologies, i.e. not revealing the origin to the researchers. Examples:

  • In Buenos Aires, the sample was taken in front of witnesses and TV cameras and was examined under blinding conditions by multiple labs and institutions including Vanora M. Kean (LinkedIn) at Forensic Analytical Crime Lab (founded in 1994), Dr. Thomas Loy (ResearchGate) at the University of Queensland, and Dr. Frederick Zugibe, chief medical examiner of Rockland County, NY.

  • In Tixtla, 3mm-sized fragments of the bloodstained host were sent under blinding conditions to multiple labs including Dr. Orlando Rodas Pernillo and Dr. Elisa Hernández de Rodas, specialists in Surgical, Oncological, Gastrointestinal Pathology and Cytology at Patología Médica (founded in 1993), as well as Gene-Ex Genetics Laboratory.

Where are the triple-blind studies and peer reviews? Why aren’t these published in scientific journals?

Triple-blind studies, by definition, involve repeatable experiments, and the peer review process is likewise designed for experiments that can be independently reproduced and observed. Eucharist miracles, on the other hand, are one-off events that cannot be deliberately recreated or instigated for study.

Also a complete and verifiable chain of custody is critical for the scientific community to accept the validity of any specimen used in research. In the case of Eucharistic miracles, this is impossible because the specimens appeared spontaneously in Catholic parishes (i.e. non-laboratory settings) at unforeseen times and circumstances, and the scientific studies commenced only after the hosts had already changed into flesh.

Finally, supernatural phenomena are still a taboo topic in science today, as demonstrated by the events surrounding these Eucharistic miracles:

Legnica, Poland

  • Cardiologist Dr. Barbara Engel: “In fact, not all the scientists and organizations that initially participated in this study agreed to give an opinion. Many withdrew, citing various reasons after learning the origin of this sample. In the end, two organizations issued a scientific opinion. These are the Institute of Forensic Medicine in Wrocław and the Institute of Forensic Medicine in Szczecin.”

Sokolka, Poland

  • Professors Sobaniec-Łotowska and Sulkowski were formally reprimanded by their director for carrying out “illegal” and “disloyal” investigations (these accusations were unsubstantiated, and both professors are still employed by the same university today, more than 10 years later).

  • The head of the Polish Rationalist Association initiated a public lawsuit calling for a murder investigation under the rationale that the heart tissue must have come from a dead person.

Buenos Aires, Argentina

  • Professor Susanne Hummel at the University of Göttingen declined to take on the case “because if the testing confirmed what was being claimed, namely that a communion host had become flesh or blood, then this would embarrass the university and force it to close down part of the university as some of its programs and activities were founded on atheism” (quoted from the book Unseen New Evidence: the Origin of Life Under the Microscope).

Bread and Wine Transformed

Hundreds of Eucharistic phenomena—evident miracles of consecrated bread and wine physically transforming into flesh and blood—have been recorded over the last millennium across the globe. Since many scientific and technological advances have arisen over the past century, several of these proclaimed miracles have only recently been thoroughly investigated.

When people hear that a “miracle” has happened, many are rightfully skeptical. Unfortunately, history is full of examples of so-called miracles exposed as fraud. The Church hesitates to jump on any swelling excitement incited by growing masses of hopeful believers and meticulously investigates each claim of a miracle (often to the point of frustration of the eager faithful), carefully looking for signs of subterfuge. If the Church declared that an event was a miracle and it turned out to be a hoax, the result could significantly damage the people’s faith and the Church’s credibility. Therefore, the Church is cautious to uphold only events that withstand rigorous testing; thorough testing and validation ensure that such events illuminate the truth and bolster people’s faith. The official Church process can take years to definitively confirm an event as a phenomenon that defies scientific explanation (i.e., a true miracle).

Many religious statues that purportedly bleed or weep have been exposed as hoaxes by the Catholic Church. For example, a church custodian was accused of using his own blood to simulate a bleeding statue after the DNA of the blood on the statue was found to match his own DNA. Other fake materials used such as red paint or perfumed olive oil are easily identifiable through chemical analyses. In other cases where fraud is not at play, a scientific explanation may offer a simple answer: A “weeping” statue can develop condensation on its cooler surfaces, such as the eyes.

In contrast, the five Eucharistic phenomena that we will evaluate all stood up to extensive scientific investigations. The Church enlisted secular institutions to conduct medical and laboratory analyses to critically evaluate the evidence. Scientists scrutinized histological specimens of the transformed tissue under the microscope and performed a variety of laboratory tests to help determine their composition and characteristics.

In all five events, the tests revealed the presence of not only real flesh but heart muscle, specifically. In two of these events, blood was also present and identified in both as type AB, a rare blood type found in only 7% of the world’s population. Almost every scientific investigation of the real world is going to have some limitations, but what makes these phenomena compelling is the similar findings across events separated by thousands of miles and, in one case, over a thousand years. We will first focus on each case under the microscope before we zoom out to take a big picture look at what makes these phenomena so intriguing as a whole.

Sokolka, Poland (2008)

One of the  Eucharistic phenomena occurred at St. Anthony of Padua Church in Sokolka, a small town in northeastern Poland. On October 12, 2008, a priest placed a consecrated host (the consecrated bread given to the faithful during Mass) in a container of water after it had fallen to the ground. Sister Julia Dubowska, the parish sacristan, placed the container in the sacristy’s safe. One week later, she was astonished to find a red substance connected to a partially dissolved host in the container. She quickly informed the other priests, who were stunned by the transformation. 

After 18 days in water, the tissue and the host—which had not fully dissolved—was moved to a linen cloth and left to dry. Two months later, the archbishop asked two anatomical pathologists from the Medical University of Bialystok to conduct a scientific investigation of the tissue. Professor Maria Elżbieta Sobaniec-Łotowska and Professor Stanislaw Sulkowski were both highly respected pathologists who had published dozens of research articles in peer-reviewed journals. Sobaniec-Łotowska took a small sample of the red portion, along with its connection to the host, and gave half of it to Sulkowski for microscopic analysis. He was not told of its origins at first so that he could independently analyze the tissue without prior biases. The two professors each came to the same conclusion: the samples were heart muscle.

There are three types of muscle in the human body: skeletal, smooth, and cardiac. Cardiac muscle tissue, also called the myocardium, is only found in the heart and characterized by particular structures that can be identified under the microscope. Sobaniec-Łotowska and Sulkowski used light and electron microscopy to identify the samples as cardiac tissue.

The remnant of the 2008 Sokolka host, where the red tissue is joined to a host fragment (top left). The underlying surface is a linen corporal with an embroidered red cross.

The monstrance displaying the host at St. Anthony of Padua Church in Sokolka

The monstrance displaying the host at St. Anthony of Padua Church in Sokolka

The Polish newspaper Nasz Dziennik interviewed Sobaniec-Łotowska and Sulkowski in December 2009:

Sulkowski: If we put the Communion wafer in the water, in the normal course of events it should dissolve in a short time. In this case, however, part of the Communion, for some incomprehensible reason, did not dissolve. Moreover, what is even more incomprehensible—the tissue that appeared on the Communion was tightly connected to it—infiltrating the substrate on which it was formed. Take my word for it that even if someone had intended to manipulate it, he would not have been able to connect the two structures so inseparably.

Sulkowski found two things astounding about this sample. First, the Communion wafer, which contains only wheat flour and water, did not decompose, as any unleavened bread soaked in water would do after 18 days. Second, the bread and cardiac muscle tissues were intricately interwoven in a way that would be impossible to accomplish through human manipulation.

Sobaniec-Łotowska: This remarkable phenomenon of the intermingling of the Communion and the fibers of the heart muscle observed in both light microscopes and transmission electron microscopy also demonstrates to me that there could be no human interference here. In addition, please note another unusual phenomenon. The Communion stayed in the water for a long time, and then even longer on the corporal. Thus, the tissue that appeared in the Communion should have undergone a process of autolysis [Editor’s note: a type of necrosis]. Examining the collected material, we found no such changes. I think that at the current stage of development of knowledge, we are not able to explain the studied phenomenon solely based on natural science.

Transmission electron microscopy, a tool far more powerful than light microscopy, is used to visualize incredibly small details, including viral particles and atoms. After using this sensitive tool, Sobaniec-Łotowska agreed with Sulkowski’s assessment of the interwoven fibers. This integration could not have been achieved by any human craft. She also affirmed that the cardiac tissue should’ve decomposed as any fleshy tissue would when separated from a living body. Instead, the cardiac tissue remained intact without any signs of degradation.

Sobaniec-Łotowska: Together, we would like to highlight the fact that in the case of the Communion fragment we studied, it was possible to observe so many morphologically characteristic markers indicative of myocardial tissue in such a small amount of collected material. One such marker is the phenomenon of segmentation, i.e., damage to the myocardial fibers at the site of the insertions [Editor’s note: structures characteristic of the heart muscle] and the phenomenon of fragmentation. This damage is visible as small cracks. Such changes occur only in non-necrotic fibers and reflect the rapid contraction of the heart muscle in the premortem agonal period.

The two professors noted fragmentation in the heart tissue. Fragmentation indicates that the heart is undergoing extreme stress while the heart cells are still alive. This finding would not occur after the tissue had already died, suggesting that the body the tissue came from had been suffering while still alive.

Sobaniec-Łotowska: Another important piece of evidence that the examined material could be human heart muscle was the mainly central arrangement of cell nuclei in the observed fibers, which is a characteristic phenomenon for this muscle. On the course of some fibers, we also found images that could correspond to nodes of contraction. On the other hand, electron microscope examination showed outlines of insertions and bundles of delicate myofibrils. In the summary of the expertise carried out, in the protocol submitted to the archdiocesan curia, we stated: “The material sent for evaluation [...] in the opinion of two independent pathomorphologists is satisfactory; it indicates myocardial tissue, or at least of all the living tissues of the body, that most closely resembles it.” And what we think is important: the material we analyzed is this tissue in its entirety.

After independently examining this tissue with light and electron microscopes, both professors concluded that the sampled tissue was heart muscle.

Because of these astonishing findings, Sobaniec-Łotowska and Sulkowski were formally reprimanded by their university and accused of carrying out “illegal” and “disloyal” investigations that incorporated the “emotional” aspect of their Catholic faith. A tabloid magazine article speculated that the red substance might have been bacterial contamination with Serratia marcescens, even though these rod-shaped bacteria do not resemble heart muscle tissue under the microscope. The president of the Polish Rationalist Association even initiated a public lawsuit calling for the district attorney of Sokolka to launch a criminal investigation for murder since the heart tissue must have come from someone who was no longer alive.

Sulkowski defended what he did:

We have the duty to investigate every scientific problem… Just as a doctor cannot refuse to care for a patient, likewise, we have the duty to research every scientific problem, according to the guidelines of the Polish Academy of Sciences.

The problem with their report was that, as Sobaniec-Łotowska stated in her interview, “we are not able to explain the studied phenomenon solely based on natural science.” Why did the host not dissolve after 18 days in water? Why did the heart muscle not show any autolytic changes or other signs of decomposition after being immersed as well? How did the muscle and host become intertwined in such a fashion that two experts in the field independently concluded that a human could not have fabricated it? Science cannot currently offer satisfactory answers to these questions.

It is natural then to consider the possibility of fraud. In Sokolka, only two people had keys to access the container that held the transformed host. But let’s imagine that someone got access and wished to publicize a miracle to garner attention for themselves or the Church. It’s difficult to envision such a person going to the trouble—even if they had the ability—to fabricate a piece of heart tissue elaborately interwoven with bread in the anticipation that it would later be examined under an electron microscope. 

Reporting these scientifically inexplicable findings only harmed Sobaniec-Łotowska and Sulkowski’s professional reputations at their university, so they lack any obvious motive for colluding or falsifying these strange results when both professors were already well-known and respected for publishing traditional scientific journal articles. On the contrary, it appears that their rigorous  scientific approach convinced them to stand by their objective findings despite the surrounding controversy. Their results highlight both the usefulness of science in microscopically confirming a tissue’s identity and the limits of current science to explain everything. If this event was a Eucharistic miracle, these mystifying findings are part of the miracle. 

Professor Maria Sobaniec-Łotowska
Medical University of Bialystok

Research Gate (129 publications)

Professor Stanislaw Sulkowski
Medical University of Bialystok

Research Gate (298 publications)

Legnica, Poland (2013)

Five years later and 400 miles to the southwest, another Eucharistic phenomenon occurred in Legnica, Poland. During the first Christmas morning Mass of 2013 at Sanctuary of St. Hyacinth, a consecrated host accidentally fell on the ground during the Communion distribution. Following standard procedure, the priest placed the host in a metal chalice filled with tap water and left it in the tabernacle to dissolve.

On January 5, 2014, another priest at St. Hyacinth, Father Andrzej Ziombra, went to check on the host. He reported this discovery:

Immediately we noticed that the Host had not dissolved, and that a red spot covering a fifth of Its surface appeared. We decided to inform the Bishop, who established a special theological scientific commission to analyze the event. We noticed that over time the stain on the Host changed color from deep red to red brown.

Over the next two weeks, the rest of the host dissolved in the water and only the red portion remained (see pictures below documenting the changes over time). One month later, this red material was placed onto a corporal cloth and left to dry. Fifteen specimens were taken from this red tissue in the presence of witnesses with each step of the sampling process photographed. Control samples were also prepared from both non-consecrated bread and consecrated hosts from the same production batch as the host that had developed the red tissue. The Institutes of Forensic Medicine at two Polish universities, Wrocław Medical University and Pomeranian Medical University, studied these samples. A lab report from Pomeranian Medical University identified the tissue as human heart muscle.  

Dr. Barbara Engel, head of the cardiology department at the Provincial Specialist Hospital in Legnica, was a member of the ecclesiastical committee overseeing the investigations. She discussed the findings in an interview with Olivier Bault from the French newspaper Présent in December 2016. 

Bault: I would like to start with a very practical question. I would like to know if for you personally, as a scientist who was part of the team that studied this transformed eucharist, it has been established beyond any doubt that the sample examined was indeed tissue similar to muscle tissue from a dying human heart, because that's what I've read about this phenomenon.

Engel: What I can say is that the material examined is muscle tissue from a human heart—which can be confirmed by the DNA found there—and the alterations observed in this myocardial tissue correspond to those from the heart of a dying man.

Histological slides identified this tissue as muscle from a heart. Although the tissue had undergone significant decomposition with autolytic changes (tissue breaks down as cells release enzymes) certain structural details were still visible that were most consistent with cardiac muscle.

In particular, the histological images show the fragmentation of muscle fibers, which can occur, as the report states, “in the overload of cardiac muscle … often accompanied by the effects of myocardial hypoxia or ventricular fibrillation in the case of the myocardium; changes of this type in the case of cardiac muscle are often accompanied by agony.” As discussed in the Sokolka section, this type of fragmentation only occurs while the tissue is still living and suggests that the heart muscle was undergoing significant stress while the person was still alive.

Bault: Has this DNA been analyzed?

Engel: Yes, of course, it was analyzed using the amplification technique, which twice yielded DNA of human origin.

The commission detected human DNA in the tissue through DNA amplification.

Bault: I read that two research organizations have studied this host.

Engel: In fact, not all the scientists and organizations that initially participated in this study agreed to give an opinion. Many withdrew, citing various reasons after learning the origin of this sample. In the end, two organizations issued a scientific opinion. These are the Institute of Forensic Medicine in Wrocław and the Institute of Forensic Medicine in Szczecin.

Bault: Did those who withdrew question the nature of this matter?

Engel: No, they agreed that it was myocardial tissue, but when told where this fragment came from they refused to write an opinion.

The reluctance of scientists and institutions to publicize their findings underscores why the Eucharistic phenomena are not discussed more widely among scientific circles. According to Engel, other scientists agreed that the tissue was myocardial when they were not aware of its origins. Why did they refuse to continue once they were told where it came from? 

Translated excerpt of the report from Pomeranian Medical University

Dr. Barbara Engel, a cardiologist on the Legnica ecclesiastical committee

The monstrance containing the tissue at St. Hyacinth’s Church

After two weeks, the host almost completely dissolved while the red tissue remained.

The tissue was removed from the water and placed on a cloth for later analysis.

The red color appeared on the host while it was dissolving in water.

The red portion detached from the host a few days later.

The Medical University of Bialystok’s reprimand of Sobaniec-Łotowska and Sulkowski in Sokolka just five years earlier probably did not inspire confidence that yet another report of heart muscle appearing on bread would be well received by the scientific community. Many scientists may be reluctant to be associated with any event described as miraculous even if their investigation would be based in science. Even if their slides had shown heart tissue, they may still have had doubts about where it came from.

Bault: We could read in the newspaper Gazeta Wyborcza, and therefore in an article written by people who were not necessarily believers, that the method of taking the samples had not fulfilled the criteria usually accepted for this kind of analysis, particularly in forensic medicine. Is it true?

Engel: If that's what we read, the author of that article was misinformed. He would have had to find out how the material was taken, which obviously was not the case. The samples were taken by the Institute of Forensic Medicine in Wrocław (Zakład Medycyny Sądowej we Wrocławiu). The whole procedure was recorded, documented, and described. The scientists, when taking the samples, filmed and photographed everything. The collection of samples for analysis was done in an absolutely professional manner. Then, the procedures carried out in the laboratories of this institute were in turn documented. Each sample has been properly isolated, described, packaged, transported, etc. In scientific circles, the procedure followed did not raise any questions.

As part of its thorough investigation, the commission was careful to document every step when sampling the tissue and sending it for laboratory analysis. However, the Gazeta Wyborcza article referenced by Bault criticizes the results because Pomeranian Medical University received the sample already prepared within a paraffin block, which meant that the DNA detected by amplification could have been due to contamination from the person preparing the tissue. As in Sokolka, the possibility of bacterial contamination with Serratia marcescens, a type of bacteria that produces a vivid red pigment called prodigiosin, was also discussed as a cause for the red coloring. This might be a valid consideration when discussing the appearance of red substances on bread in the past before microscopes were available, but this argument is not applicable to the cardiac tissues seen in Sokolka and Legnica. There is no way that anyone who has taken an introductory class in microbiology could mistake a colony of rod-shaped bacteria for muscle tissue on a histological slide.

DNA can successfully be obtained from paraffin blocks, but for the sake of argument, let’s go along with the criticism and agree that the DNA detected was just contamination from someone who had handled the samples. Suppose the bacterial contamination caused the red substance in the first place. Neither of these propositions explains the heart muscle that was seen under the microscope. 

In the end, comparing the two phenomena in Legnica and Sokolka reveals some striking parallels. Something red appears on a host left to dissolve in water. When the tissue is analyzed, the specimen turns out to be cardiac muscle with evidence of fragmentation, suggesting stress to the heart while the tissue was still alive. In both cases, the public criticisms of these studies did not address the literal heart of the matter clearly visible under the microscope.

We now have many scientific tools at our disposal that can help analyze and shed light on mysterious events. Just as the Catholic Church has welcomed scientific investigation of religious phenomena, perhaps the scientific community should be more open to investigating these events to the extent possible. Scientific progress is jeopardized when scientists do not report objective findings about religious phenomena because they are afraid of tarnishing their professional reputation in the scientific community.

Bault: And so, to recap, from your point of view there is no doubt that we are dealing here with a Eucharistic miracle?

Engel: For me, as for everyone who has seen this Host up close, there is no doubt that it is a miracle. That said, medicine is an exact science but theology, contrary to appearances, is also an exact science. Here, the bishop tells us, as the Church teaches, that to say that there is a Eucharistic miracle, this transformation of the Host must be accompanied by extraordinary phenomena. This is why we speak here of an “event having the characteristics of a Eucharistic miracle.” This event is now observed. It is only if other inexplicable events occur around this Host that we will speak in the future of a “Eucharistic miracle.” So much for the theological side. But as far as I am concerned, I am not a theologian and it is indeed a miracle.

Bault: So I come back to my question: what has changed in your life?

Engel: It is difficult for me to answer this question, but I can say without hesitation that I received a huge injection of faith. This has been accompanied by many graces in my daily life.

This “injection of faith” may be part of the extraordinary phenomena accompanying what the bishop (and the Church) describes as an “event having the characteristics of a Eucharistic miracle.” Moreover, this investigation demonstrates how science can coexist with religion and even nourish faith in events that science cannot fully explain.

Fragment of striated muscle fiber with visible fragmentation

Another piece of the material with visible fragmentation

Tixtla, Mexico (2006)

Poland is not the only country that has witnessed Eucharistic miracles. Let’s look at another transformation that took place across the Atlantic Ocean in Tixtla, Mexico. In 2006, Father Leopoldo Roque, pastor of the Parish of Saint Martin of Tours, invited Father Raymundo Reyna Esteban to lead a spiritual retreat for his parishioners. Father Raymundo, known affectionately as “Father Rayito,” was a popular preacher in his fifties who managed (and still manages as of this publication) a radio and TV channel called Monte María Radio y Televisión.

People from all over came to hear their dear Father Rayito speak. The 600 retreat attendants filed into the spacious municipal auditorium to celebrate the Sunday Mass on October 22, 2006. During the Communion distribution, Sister Arely Marroquín noticed one of the hosts exuding a reddish substance that looked like fresh blood. The Eucharistic host was reserved for later study.

The bleeding host of Tixtla shortly after the event on October 22, 2006

Father Raymundo Reyna Esteban shows the bleeding host to the attendees of Mass at the Tixtla town hall auditorium on October 22, 2006.

In the weeks following the event, Monsignor Alejo Zavala Castro, the bishop of the local diocese of Chilpancingo, set up an inquiry committee that collected the sworn testimonies of witnesses. Three years later, Dr. Ricardo Castañón Gómez, who had developed an interest in studying Eucharistic phenomena, contacted Bishop Castro after attending a nearby conference. Dr. Castañón Gómez had founded a company, Grupo Internacional para la Paz, that recorded the sampling of relics and forwarded them to a wide network of laboratories in a “clear, unbroken and documented chain of custody” under blinded conditions where the researchers analyzing the tissues were unaware of their origins. He was eventually appointed to begin investigations of the Tixtla host in 2009 and collected samples that were sent to forensic medical labs in several countries.

Dr. Orlando Rodas Pernillo and Dr. Elisa Hernández de Rodas, specialists in Surgical, Oncological, Gastrointestinal Pathology and Cytology at Patología Médica, reported the following:

  • The architectural fibers showed bifurcations, which can be seen in cardiac muscle. The structure of the tissue was consistent with muscle tissue from the heart, but definitive microscopic identification was not possible because of the decomposition of the sample. (Immunohistochemical tests by another lab confirmed that this was cardiac muscle, as described later.)

  • The sample had autolytic changes, but histological structures were still visible: adipose cells, erythrocytes, neutrophils, eosinophils, and even a macrophage phagocytosing lipids. Despite the degradation of the sample, the scientists could still visualize fat cells, red blood cells, and several types of white blood cells: neutrophils, eosinophils, and macrophages. The microscope slide even captured a macrophage in the middle of phagocytosing—ingesting—fatty debris.

The Gene-Ex Genetics Laboratory in Bolivia found the following:

  • An immunoassay for the detection of human hemoglobin was positive. Hemoglobin is a type of protein found in red blood cells. This test was specific for the human version of hemoglobin, confirming that the blood was human.

  • The human blood was type AB negative. The AB negative blood type is the rarest blood type in the world, comprising less than 1% of the population.

Longitudinal fibers with bifurcations, typically seen in cardiac muscle.

On the left, a group of erythrocytes, with a neutrophil and an eosinophil immersed among them. On the right, a vacuolated cell.

Dr. Eduardo Sánchez Lazo, a professor of Legal and Forensic Medicine at the National Autonomous University of Mexico, also studied a sample and signed a statement with the following conclusions:

  • “The immunological study shows that the blood is of a human, and the immunohistochemical test allows us to state with all objectivity and certainty that it belongs to blood group AB.” This confirmed the findings from the Gene-Ex laboratory.

  • “After immunohistochemical tests, it has been determined that the tissue under study corresponds to the heart due to its macroscopic characteristics, in addition to showing the aforementioned cytochemical results.” This lab was able to confirm that this was cardiac tissue through immunohistochemical testing.

  • “The sample presents … an outflow of blood from its interior to its periphery, that is, the blood comes from the interior to the exterior… The possibility that the bleeding comes from the outside inwards is ruled out.” To evaluate for signs of fraud, Bishop Castro had requested that the doctor study whether the blood-like substance had been added to the host from the outside. Dr. Lazo confirmed that there was no external source of blood and that it originated from the inside. 

In contrast to the Polish investigations by scientists at nearby universities, this investigation engaged multiple laboratories and scientists in different countries who worked independently from one another. They were not told where the specimen came from or what the other laboratories had found. The laboratories used diverse, complementary techniques—microscopic evaluation and an array of immunological and biochemical tests—to analyze the sample and ultimately arrived at the same conclusion: This was heart muscle and type AB human blood.

The extensive investigations of the Tixtla host confirmed that this was truly biological tissue, containing muscle, fat cells, red blood cells, and white blood cells. Furthermore, the human blood came from the interior of the host and spread outward instead of originating from the outside, which calls to mind Sobaniec-Łotowska’s assertion that “no human interference” could have created the intermingled bread and heart tissue in Sokolka. Underlying these findings is the same tissue that was present at both Eucharistic events in Poland. Despite all odds, heart muscle is inexplicably found in every Eucharistic phenomenon discussed on this page.

Buenos Aires, Argentina (1996)

At St. Mary’s Church in Buenos Aires, Argentina, consecrated hosts were found to exude a reddish substance on three occasions in 1992, 1994, and 1996. We will focus on the 1996 phenomenon since the sample from this event was the one studied most extensively. On August 18, 1996, a parishioner found a discarded host on a candleholder and brought it to a priest, who immersed it in water and locked it in the tabernacle. Eight days later, a red substance that resembled blood clots was discovered in the water, along with the dissolving host. After a month in tap water, this red substance was transferred to a bottle of distilled water.

In 1999, Dr. Castañón, the same founder of Grupo Internacional para la Paz who studied the Tixtla phenomenon, became interested in investigating the Eucharistic events at St. Mary’s Church. The archbishop of Buenos Aires approved his request to start an investigation that would document the sampling process and chain of custody. On October 5, 1999, TV cameras showed Dr. Castañón taking a sample from the 1996 event, which had now spent three years immersed in water.

The sample was flown to New York to be examined by Dr. Frederick Zugibe, the chief medical examiner of Rockland County, New York. Dr. Zugibe was an adjunct Associate Professor of Pathology at Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons, a Fellow of the College of American Pathologists, a Fellow of the American Academy of Forensic Sciences, and a member of the National Association of Medical Examiners. Dr. Zugibe was not told of its origins until he had analyzed the slides and given his opinion. He concluded that the sample contained cardiac tissue and declared the following in a letter:

The slide consists of cardiac (heart) tissue that displays degenerative changes of the myocardial tissue (cardiac muscular tissue) with loss of striations, nuclear pyknosis, aggregates of mixed inflammatory cells consisting of aggregates of chronic inflammatory cells (macrophages) which are the predominant cells admixed with smaller numbers of acute inflammatory cells (white blood cells primarily polymorphonuclear leukocytes). The directionality of the myocardial fibers indicates that the site of these changes is relatively close to a valvular region in the ventricular area of the heart.

When Dr. Zugibe looked at the tissue under the microscope, he found heart tissue that showed signs of significant inflammation. Clusters of white blood cells, including macrophages, suggested that this inflammation had occurred while the tissue was still alive. 

These degenerative changes are consistent with a recent myocardial infarction of a few days duration due to an obstruction of a coronary artery that supplies nutrients and oxygen to an area of heart muscle. The above type changes suggests that the individual had a heart attack a few days prior to death due to obstruction of a coronary artery due to atherosclerosis (a process of fatty plaque buildup in the coronary artery), or due to a coronary thrombosis (clot formation within a coronary artery), the latter either caused by the atherosclerosis process or to injury to the chest wall, causing injury to the coronary arteries that supply oxygen and nutrients to the heart muscle. The dating of the injury is derived from the finding of a predominance of chronic inflammatory cells, degenerative changes of the myocardium with loss of striations, pyknosis of the nuclei, etc.

The changes in the heart tissue were likely caused by a significant event, such as a heart attack or injury to the chest wall.

When I was later told that the heart tissue was kept in tap water for about a month and transferred to sterile, distilled water for three years, I indicated that it would be impossible to see white blood cells or macrophages in the sample. Moreover, it would be impossible to identify the tissue per se as there would be no morphological characteristics.

How did the muscle and white blood cells remain intact after being stored in water for three years? Flesh would completely decompose in water after three years, and white blood cells cannot survive in plain water. They only remain viable in liquids with certain electrolyte concentrations; the osmotic gradient will burst white blood cells in plain water. White blood cells were seen in the Tixtla host as well, but that tissue had never been immersed in liquid. Their survival in water here is scientifically inexplicable and perhaps just as extraordinary to a pathologist as seeing bread turn into flesh in the first place.

Here, as in Poland, a reddish substance is found on a host left to dissolve and eventually identified as injured cardiac muscle under the microscope. Recall the fragmentation seen in the heart muscle at Sokolka and Legnica that also suggested injury to the heart while it was still alive. 

By now these events and findings feel familiar, even if separated by years and thousands of miles. But these are all relatively recent phenomena. Could these events share any similarities with a Eucharistic phenomenon that took place over a thousand years ago?

Lanciano, Italy (~700 AD)

One of the earliest recorded Eucharistic miracles occurred at the monastery of Saints Legonziano and Domiziano around AD 700 in Anxanum (today known as Lanciano, Italy). As a Basilian hieromonk spoke the Words of Consecration—“This is my body. . . . This is my blood.”—he felt the bread change into flesh and saw the wine transform into blood, which coagulated into five globules. 

The Basilian monks knew they had been entrusted with something precious. They kept custody of the elements for centuries until the order departed from Italy in 1175. Benedictine monks succeeded them as custodians of the Eucharistic elements. 

The Church has carefully preserved these treasures throughout the centuries. A silver monstrance, crafted in 1713, encapsulates the host changed to flesh. A 17th-century crystal chalice contains the wine turned to blood. Both monstrance and chalice, providing a clear view of the contents, are held in a marble case on top of the main altar in Lanciano’s Church of San Francesco. The sanctuary attracts thousands of pilgrims every year from all over the world.

More than a thousand years after this Eucharistic transformation, the archbishop of Lanciano hoped to use modern scientific tools to study this ancient mystery. In 1970, Santa Maria Sopra i Ponti Hospital in Arezzo, Italy, sent Dr. Odoardo Linoli, head of the Laboratory of Pathological Anatomy, to examine the specimens in depth. On November 18, 1970, the archbishop broke the seals from 1886 (the last time the specimens had been taken out) in front of witnesses, and several samples were taken from the desiccated flesh and clots of blood. After examining the flesh under the microscope and subjecting the samples to various assays for several months, he concluded that the flesh was human heart muscle and that the clots were human blood, both blood type AB. Linoli published his results in the September 1971 issue of Quaderni Sclavo di Diagnostica Clinica e di Laboratori. An English translation of his findings is provided in Appendix III, and an excerpt of his conclusions is below:

“The Blood of the Eucharistic Miracle of Lanciano was truly blood, as demonstrated by the detection of hemoglobin (alkaline hematin) with thin-layer chromatography.” Linoli confirmed that the clumps were blood by testing for hemoglobin, the same oxygen-carrying protein in red blood cells that was found in the blood sample in Tixtla, Mexico. 

  • “The Flesh consisted of muscle tissue, which, due to the syncytial arrangement of the fibers, was shown to belong to the myocardium.” Linoli identified the histological structure of the flesh under the microscope as myocardium, another term for heart muscle tissue. In a letter dated February 26, 1971, Ruggero Bertelli, a professor of human anatomy at the University of Siena, also looked at these slides and agreed that the flesh appeared to be myocardial muscle tissue.

  • “The Flesh and Blood belong to the human species, as ascertained by the Uhlenhuth test.” The Uhlenhuth test found the presence of proteins specific to humans.

  • “The blood group . . . was identical (AB) in the Flesh and Blood.” Both the flesh and blood were found to have the same rare blood type—AB—which was also the blood type of the Tixtla blood. The Rh factor was not determined, so it is unknown if it would have also matched the Rh negative blood in Tixtla.

  • “In the blood elution liquid, the relative distribution of proteins has been observed to be similar to that of normal fresh blood, but with some deviations due to the age of the sample.” After the coagulated blood had been turned into a liquid by macerating a small fragment with distilled water, a protein electrophoresis test showed that it had the same types of proteins (albumin and several types of globulins) in the typical proportions that would be expected for fresh blood.

  • “It should also be noted that no histological section showed elements indicative of an impregnation of the tissue by mummifying substances, such as those used in ancient times for the preservation of tissues.” There was no evidence that any preservatives were used to keep these tissues intact.

The above analysis was revisited a decade later and reported in a 1982 issue of the Vatican daily newspaper L'Osservatore Romano. Linoli prepared new histological sections from a small piece of Eucharistic flesh that had been saved but not examined in 1970. 

With the new slides, Linoli was able to see new structural details, such as the internal lining of the heart, blood vessels, and even vagus nerve fibers. The reissued publication summarized these new microscopic findings, describing how these fibers and tissues outlined a picture of a complete human heart.

Furthermore, these microscopic details support how the Lanciano flesh appears to the eye: a thin transverse section of the heart with the remains of the left ventricle in the lower portion and the right ventricle in the upper portion (photograph below). When considering the question of fraud, Linoli noted in his report that “even supposing that the heart had been taken from a corpse, it must be assumed that only an expert hand in anatomy could, and not without serious difficulties, obtain a hollow uniform and continuous ‘slice’ from a hollow viscus, considering that the first human anatomical dissections took place after the 14th century,” 600 years after this tissue was discovered.

Some of the details of the original event have been lost over time, but it is amazing to think about these tissues—heart muscle and blood—remaining intact for over 1200 years without any preservatives. Their preservation echoes some of the other Eucharistic miracles we have discussed where bread does not dissolve, and white blood cells survive for years in plain water. 

Perhaps these findings are so amazing that one has to consider the possibility of fraud, but what would be the motivation for obtaining genuine human heart and blood tissue in AD 700, especially considering the degree of skill required to obtain a thin cross-section of the human heart? Did someone anticipate a thorough scientific examination centuries later?

One could point out that Linoli was mostly working alone, in contrast to some of the other investigations we have discussed where multiple scientists worked independently and ran tests without knowing the origin of the specimens. Nonetheless, his report highlights the care he took in methodically running an array of tests, including controls, extensively documenting his results, and asking for a second opinion from Bertelli on the histological slides. Most convincing of all is how his work parallels the results of scientific investigations of similar events decades later. All five of the Eucharistic phenomena we have discussed found cardiac muscle tissue; when a blood type was obtained, it was type AB in both cases. When we look at all five of these phenomena together, explaining them all away as coincidence or conspiracy becomes more and more unfathomable.

Seeing the Big Picture

We have focused on these five Eucharistic phenomena because their scientific investigations offer objective findings that go beyond witness accounts. Incredibly, in all five cases, the red tissue that appeared from consecrated hosts was identified as heart muscle, usually with signs of stress and inflammation. When blood was also present (in Tixtla and Lanciano), the blood type was identified as the rare AB type in both cases. Of course, the sudden appearance of physical flesh and blood on Eucharistic elements was mysterious, but some of these phenomena were also attended by other mysteries: In Sokolka, how did the flesh not show any signs of decomposition? How did it become so intertwined with bread and not dissolve in the water? In Buenos Aires, how did the flesh and white blood cells remain intact after three years of immersion in water? 

Fraud in all five events would require an elaborate conspiracy orchestrated by the scientific investigators and Church officials, a high degree of sophistication, a painstaking amount of work, and an airtight collusion among multiple institutions across multiple continents spanning several decades. And if fraud were involved, why would conspirators deliberately choose tissues and blood types that were hard to obtain? The Church has exposed many hoaxes about purported miracles over the years, and most involve simple substances that are readily identifiable as non-human. By the way, none of these confirmed hoaxes has involved the Eucharist, though the Church has uncovered natural explanations for several reported Eucharistic “miracles,” e.g. red stains caused by bacteria that grew on hosts that dropped on the floor.

No matter how difficult it might have been to perpetuate a fraud across all these phenomena, it is understandable that skeptics might still assume duplicity of some kind rather than believe in the existence of miracles that defy our current scientific understanding. They may want to see more extraordinary evidence for these extraordinary claims. Although the results of these scientific investigations are compelling in aggregate, they are not airtight. No one was warned ahead of time that a particular host was going to transform into heart muscle so that a video camera could continuously record it before, during, and after the event. These events did not occur in a laboratory setting where they could be repeatedly tested with every variable controlled. Several of these investigations documented the sampling process and chain of custody and blinded researchers to the samples’ origins until after they had analyzed them, but there are limits to what can be controlled in the real world.

So, if someone requires extraordinary evidence to believe in a miracle, there is probably never going to be enough evidence to satisfy them that a miracle has occurred. But consider for a moment this question: “What is the probability that the evidence for a particular miracle would exist if the miracle never occurred?” Despite the controversy surrounding the Sokolka and Legnica events in Poland, no rebuttals have offered a convincing explanation for the heart muscle that was discovered. Viable alternative explanations have also not been offered  in Tixtla, Buenos Aires, or Lanciano, for that matter. What is the probability that all these findings—the matching AB blood types, the mysterious heart tissue, sometimes interwoven with bread or white blood cells that shouldn’t have remained intact—would have been discovered by scientists if these miracles had not actually occurred?

Dr. Castañón, the physician who was involved in the investigations in Buenos Aires and Tixtla, started out as a skeptic but ended up converting to Catholicism after his research into mystical phenomena. When considering the possibility that these events might even be the physical manifestation of the flesh and blood of Jesus Christ, many people have been moved by the findings under the microscope, including the muscle fragmentation and inflammation that speak of a heart experiencing deep pain and suffering.

Unfortunately, the general media persists in perceiving the Eucharist as a Catholic issue—something to be discussed only among members of the Catholic Church. A few of the scientists involved have given interviews to inform the public of the nature of the phenomena, but they have not been sought after for Time magazine covers or any mainstream media interviews. On the contrary, they have stayed away from the spotlight. They have done their job in carrying out their scientific investigation and have since moved on to other projects. Therefore, Eucharistic phenomena remain widely unknown beyond the Catholic world despite their extraordinary nature and significance for humanity.
